title: donald tusk contempt voters brexit leave
story: Tusk’s remark had diplomats ­practically needing the Heimlich manoeuvre to ­dislodge Ferrero Rocher chocolates stuck in their gullets. Quick, the ambassador has had a seizure!Had Herr President Tusk, at this most delicate of moments, really told the likes of Boris Johnson and Nigel Farage to go to hell  Yes, pretty much.I know we are supposed to take ­mortal offence. I know we are meant to fan our faces and ask Nurse to bring us something to soothe our nerves after that nasty man uttered such a frightful insult.But I couldn’t help laughing at toothless Tusk’s tirade.At last, a European Union bigshot has blurted out his contempt for British voters.That’s surely preferable to all those smarmy smiles and fake phrases about “respect for each other’s values” and how we hope to work with “our European friends and partners”. Real friends don’t nick £billion off you.There are two things worth knowing about Donald Tusk. The first is that in his youth he was a bit of a brawler.The ­second is that five years ago he resigned as Polish prime minister to take up his current cushy number in ­Brussels.Born in , Tusk grew up in the city of Gdansk, when Poland was a grimy ­colony of the USSR. His family had ­German roots and his dad, a carpenter, died when Donald was . It can’t have made for an easy youth.Gdansk gave rise to the Solidarity trade union ­movement which protested against Iron Curtain suppression.Tusk has recalled that in his youth he was “a typical hooligan” who would ­saunter along the streets in a gang, ­“cruising for a bruising”.In some ways, who can blame him  They were edgy days and young men will do what young men have done since time immemorial: Defend themselvesunder attack. Communism wasa ­stinking and ruinous creed.Decent Poles bravely reasserted their national sovereignty after too many decades of being governed by ideological bureaucrats who couldn’t give a fig about the electorate.Er, remind you of anything, Mister ­Eurocrat That colourful background in the Gdansk of the s and s made it all the odder when, in , Tusk quit the premiership of his country to become an EU grand fromage.He had been Poland’s PM for seven years and the country had done well.Yet he chucked that in so that he could succeed shrivelling nonentity ­Herman Van Rompuy as president of the European Council.The job is less important than it sounds. Its occupant basically acts as a collector of opinions from EU heads of government and acts as their representative at ­international shindigs.That it was held by such a blinky-eyed vole as Van Rompuy was a measure of its signicance. Yet Tusk chucked in the prime ministership of his country for it!Brussels may offer wonderful pensions, top-trough brasseries and as many rides in the back of a BMW  Series as you could wish, but had Tusk gone mad The answer to that question is “not ­necessarily”. He saw that under EU rules, national governments are now increasingly junior to the federal superpower.The real power in Brussels lies not with Tusk, nor even with boozy European ­Commission president Jean-Claude ­Juncker, but with the backroom officials such as Martin Selmayr and Sabine ­Weyand. Both of them, you may notice, are ­German. This sht in powers has ­happened slowly over decades and ­electorates have taken a while to notice.But now the voters are copping on and are at last making their ­displeasure plain.The British Leave vote was the firstgreat expression of that anger.All of which helps to explain why ­unelected EU officials have been so ­spittingly angry with the British public for voting Leave. We have busted the dam.That is why Tusk snarled at us on Wednesday. He and his sort feel badly threatened by Brexit.They feel understandably insecure about the future of the federal EU project.The Tusks of this world regard the ­peoples of Europe as an inconvenience.They were appalled with David Cameron for letting the referendum happen and they are now appalled with our MPs for not stopping Brexit.Shortly before his “hell” remark on Wednesday, Tusk expressed his disbelief that Theresa May was insisting on ­pressing ahead with Brexit, and his ­disappointment that Remainers at ­Westminster had not succeeded in blocking our departure from the EU.At that point I must confess I shouted something rude at the television in my office. “It’s because we had a f***ing ­referendum and we voted to leave!” I cried.Shouting at a TV set: Uh-oh, I may have been driven as mad by Brexit as dotty Tory Europhile Anna Soubry. Tusk’s ­outburst was similar. Everyone’s losing it!The teenage Donald Tusk — the one who used to tour the streets of Gdansk with his gang — would, I think, have ­understood. I am not recommending ­violence but politically this is certainly a time we could all do with clenching our knuckles and looking out for our interests.Cruising for a bruising, a young lad in Gdansk might once have said.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: instagram ban self harm images not enough
story: The Health Secretary said web giants were acting not a moment too soon - and insisted tough new laws are needed to keep them in line.He said that asking politely is not enough as he vowed the Government will force firms to take responsibility for users safety.Yesterday Instagram finally moved to ban graphic images of self-harm after the tragic suicide of Molly Russell, .She took her own le after being exposed to a flood of horric pictures promoting suicide and self-harm.But the firm, owned by Facebook, hasnt said when the ban will come into effect.Mr Hancock said that Instagram and other large companies such as Google and Pinterest were shocked and appalled by the content found on their services.He told Sky News: Until now, whats happened is people have called for changes and politicians have asked the social media companies to make changes.Asking politely is not enough, we need to ensure that theres enforcement so society as expressed through Government can judge what is and isnt right on social media.Were not powerless, we can and we will legislate. What you can do is require them to act in a socially responsible way.Speaking to the BBC, he added: Its every parents modern nightmare that their child will go on to Instagram and see the sort of material that encourages self-harm and encourages suicide.Social media companies shouldnt be the arbiters of this, its for society to know what is and isnt appropriate.Theyve had a blind spot towards this material that promotes self-harm and suicide and they need to deal with it.However he stopped short of backing moves to redefine social media sites as publishers.He said: “The whole concept would collapsewe make them legally ­liable for everything on their site.I would not be able to send a tweet because they would be legally responsible for it. We need something in between.”Mr Hancocks comments came just  hours after Suicide Prevention Minister Jackie Doyle-Price said she backed new laws to reclassy social media sites as publishers.She said: “We could make them responsible for their content by classing them as publishers.I do view them as publishers and I would like the law to hold them to account on that basis.”Labour deputy leader Tom Watson has also criticised the social media giants, saying: Too late to save the le of a -year-old girl, the boss of Facebook-owned Instagram is shamed by public opprobrium into changing his companys policy.But still no word from Mark Zuckerberg. Is he too cowardly, or too arrogant to speak  Or simply both And NSPCC boss Peter Wanless added: It should never have taken the death of Molly Russell for Instagram to act.“We cannot wait until the next tragedy strikes. The Government must legislate without delay and impose a duty of care on social networks, with tough punishmentsthey fail to protect their young users.”Ministers have promised to announce new laws cracking down on the web giants within weeks.

title: broken glass beheaded mother saudi arabia
story: Shia Rights Watch says that “in an unprecedented incident” the child was brutally killed in Saudi Arabia after he was confirmed to be a Shia Muslim.TMV, which has posted footage of the murdered boys funeral on its website, claims he was killed in broad daylight in the city of Medina last Thursday.The broadcaster reports that officials in Saudi Arabia said the taxi driver has mental health issues.However, local residents have claimed it was an act of sectarianism because the boy was from a Shia Muslim background.Sources close to the family alleged that Zakaria Al-Jaber was in a taxi to visit the shrine of Prophet Muhammad in Medina.However, the taxi driver stopped the car and forced the boy out near a coffee shop in the Al-Tilal neighbourhood, TMV says.The driver is then alleged to have smashed a glass bottle to obtain a shard of glass, which he then used to slash the boys throat, and stab him.His traumatised mum is said to have tried to stop the driver from attacking her boy, but collapsed on the street.Passers-by told TMV that a cop stationed nearby also tried to stop the man from attacking the boy, but he was unable to save the child.He restrained the driver until other officers arrived.Shia Rights Watch, in a press release on the boys death, said that the unknown man had asked the mothershe was Shia when they arrived at the shrine, and the woman said ‘yes’.Activists told the advocacy group, headquartered in Washington D.C., that “minutes after this conversation, the child was wrenched away from her and attacked with a broken piece of glass.The group added: “Witnesses report the child was beheaded from behind his head as his mother watched and screamed.“There was no intervention from anyone and no response from authority thus far.”The Sun Online has been unable to independently very the information.Shia Rights Watch said the Saudi Shia community “came together in mourning and to show solidarity with the parents.“The community also reported this incident is a result of ongoing violations and lack of protection by the Saudi authority toward its Shia population.”The group said that Saudi Shia “have been under a military crackdown by their government and many Shia activitists are in prisons and [sentenced to] death”.It added: “SRW, other human rights NGOs and activists have long advocated for the rights of this minority through campaigns, UN and other entities.“However the population still suffers because of the lack of international commitment to end such violations.“The beheading of a young child in such manner must be addressed as soon as possible.”The split between Sunni and Shia Muslims occurred following the death of the Prophet Muhammad – and who should succeed him.There was a schism very early on and theological dferences developed from this, explains expert Dr Carool Kersten.The Sunnis appointed the successor under Arab tribal tradition while the Shias believed Muhammad’s successor should be from his family.The name Sunni comes from “Ahl-a-Sunnah”, meaning the “people of tradition” while Shia is from “Shiat Ali” meaning “the party of Ali”.Sunni Muslims appoint a caliph as leader, while Shia Muslims appoint an imam.In regard to the schism, Dr Kersten said: “The imams were considered to be infallible, while for the Sunnis the caliph was just a man, there to maintain law and order.”Source: title: pawel relowicz mum innocent libby squire disappearance
story: Meat factory worker Pawel Relowicz, , was arrested by cops on suspicion of abducting the Hull student more than a week ago.His tearful mum Marzena, speaking from her home in Poland, told The Sun: “There is no way it could have been him.“He bakes cakes, is a religious boy and is scared of blood and violence.“I am % he will be released.”Locals in Warszewice, northern Poland, where Pawel grew up before coming to the UK five years ago, said he did not have a criminal record in the country.Friends said he last ed to Poland with his we and two children around a year ago.His snowy home village is around  miles north of Polish capital Warsaw.Some  people live there and most work in a nearby sugar beet factory.Pawels mother Marzena, speaking to The Sun inside her detached home, said: “I have a feeling Libby is alive somewhere.“I would give my le for her now to reappear safe and well and for this nightmare to come to an end.“It just does not make sense because Pawel hates violence and blood - and would cry tears and tears whenever he cut himself growing up.“I was surprised when he got the butcher job in England but he was reluctant to take it - he needed money to support his family.”Part-time veggies picker Marzena, , has not spoken to her son directly since cops swooped to arrest him at his address near Libby’s on WednesdayThey also seized his car as part of the probe.She has been getting updates from Pawel’s distraught we Jagoda back in the UK.Marzena, who lives at home with four younger sons aged from  to , sobbed: “Pawel has never hurt a woman.“I have spoken to Jogoda nearly every day throughout their entire five year relationship and she always tells me they are great together.“She never raised concerns with me about him.“When I found out he was arrested, it was like somebody had hit me with a hammer.“It tore my heart apart.“I was driving my car at the time and had to pull over before I crashed.“I have been pacing up and down non-stop since and have been shaking and crying, just praying to God that he is released soon.“I am also praying for Libby’s safeand for her parents. I think of them so much.”Marzena said Pawel occasionally played football and went to the gym in his spare time - but denied he was involved in cage fighting or martial arts as previously suggested.She said: “He didn’t need many friends or hobbies because he has seven brothers and sisters.“He has never been in trouble with the police before and has never even got into a fight with anyone.Yesterday it emerged the father-of-two offered Libby a lt in his car after spotting her distressed on the roadside after a boozy night out.Pawel’s sister Paulina, , who lives in Norway, said he was “driving and noticed a girl crying” - and stopped to take her home.She did not explain what happened after.Family sources suggested he could have been running an unofficial taxi service when he picked her up.They said: “It would not surprise me that he was doing everything he could to make extra cash.“Maybe he did not tell police during their appeal because he was scared of getting in trouble about doing paid lts for people when he shouldn’t.”Pawel, who works in a Humberside bacon factory, remained in custody last night after cops were given a  hour extension to quiz him.They have until just after pm tomorrow to charge or release him.As part of the search for Libby, police ers have been called in to search nearby lakes while officers have scoured rubbish bins and parks.It comes after the students mum Lisa Squire last night shared an emotional post, saying: One week without her, including two crying face emojis.The -year-old philosophy student was reportedly falling over drunk, two of the last people to see her say.Libby was uneasy on her feet, mumbling incomprehensibly and fell over two or three times, the witnesses said.And fears for Libbys safety escalated when a local reported hearing blood-curdling screams the night she disappeared.Sources said police acted after receiving information that led them to believe Libby may have been abducted on a street near her home.Officers insisted they were still treating her disappearance as a missing persons inquiry.The last confirmed sighting of Libby was CCTV footage of her on a park bench at .pm.Libbys parents Lisa and Russell have previously released a heartrending appeal for information, begging anyone with information to come forward. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: christopher chope tory upskirting ban blocks fgm law
story: Sir Christopher Chope stepped in to block the proposed new law using arcane Commons rules.He provoked an instant backlash from fellow Tories as top ministers said he was wrong, pure and simple.And a leading anti-FGM campaigner condemned Sir Christopher, blasting: I have nothing but disgust for this man.Tory MP Zac Goldsmith proposed a change to child welfare laws which would have allowed courts to protect children at risk of FGM.The bill, backed by the Government, was intended to stop young kids being taken abroad by their parents to undergo the horric and permanently damaging procedure.But when it was announced in the Commons today, Sir Christopher shouted object - single-handedly stopping the law from going any further.Mr Goldsmith called his actions just appalling and rubbished claims the veteran MP is only concerned about proper scrutiny of legislation.Sajid Javid added: Very disappointed by this. FGM is child abuse. I am determined to stamp out this despicable and medieval practice.And Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: Outraged Chris Chope has blocked the FGM safeguarding bill in Parliament today. His actions are wrong, pure and simple.Anti-FGM campaigner Nimco Ali personally lobbied Sir Christopher to try and convince him not to block the bill.He refused - then accused her of verbal abuse and insult when she called him an embarrassment.She said this evening: I have nothing but disgust for this man.Sir Christopher rose to notoriety last year when he intervened to block a bill outlawing upskirting - when men take photos up womens skirts.His Commons office was festooned with underwear in protest.

title: libby squire new cctv footage
story: Cops have been poring over an eight-minute video taken from a yard near a park bench where Libby, , was last seen.The footage, taken on Haworth Street in Hull, shows the male driver rolling a cigarette before helping a passenger -who police believe is second-year university student Libby - into a silver hatchback.The man then walks around to the drivers side, gets in and drives off at .am.A second film, obtained by The Sun from a shopkeeper, shows a similar car being driven along Newland Avenue, half a mile away,  minutes later, at .am.It shows a police car patrolling the same road  seconds before.:: There are more flashes before a man is seen for the first time coming into view:: He opens the door and sits facing out in the drivers side as he appears to roll a cigarette:: A cyclist rides past who could be a vital witness:: As the man smokes, another car drives past who again could hold key information:: After sitting for two minutes and  seconds, the man walks away and cars lights flash again as though it is being locked:: A person is then seen on the opposite side of the car who opens the front passenger door. Someone or something is then put inside the vehicle.:: The man reappears and gets inside the drivers seat before driving off just before nine minutes past midnight.Cops yesterday quizzed Polish butcher Pawel Relowicz, , over the two pieces of footage after they were granted a -hour extension to quiz him on abduction claims.Detectives will want to investigate whether the car in the footage is the Vauxhall Astra seized from suspect Relowicz.They obtained the CCTV last Sunday but kept it under wraps as they frantically pieced together the car’s movements before and after Libby disappeared.The Sun was aware of the crucial development before the arrest but agreed not to publish details.Shop owner and dad-of-two Mohammed Burhan, , told how his cameras picked up a car driving along Newlands Avenue the night Libby vanished.He told The Sun: “The police have been into all of the shops along here asking for CCTV footage over a particular timeframe.“They came into my shop and have taken the video from three of my cameras.“I hope my CCTV can in some way help the police find Libby and discover what has happened.”Libby was seen on the bench close to her home on Wellesley Avenue at .pm last Thursday.The Haworth Street footage was captured by cameras overlooking steel gates to an electrical firm.Staff checked it after Libby was reported missing and alerted cops.But workers there are fuming detectives took so long to reveal it.One said: “We couldn’t understand why it wasn’t published straight away by the police.“If it was my daughter I would have it everywhere.“Surely they have had enough time to examine it, obtain the licence plate and do checks to find out where it went.Time is of the essence. They always talk about the golden hour in investigations. They’ve had nearly a week.”Libby vanished after a night out with pals on Thursday January .They were turned away from a club because she was too drunk.Pals put her in a taxi to take her home and she was dropped off near her digs at around .pm.She was seen staggering in the street then sat on the bench a short time later. Police said the last time they can be sure she was in that area was .am.Cops swooped on the home that meat factory worker Relowicz shares with we Jagoda and their two kids at pm on Wednesday.Libby’s mum and dad, Lisa, , and Russ, , have travelled to Hull from their home in High Wycombe, Bucks.Senior cops insist they are still treating Libbys disappearance as a missing persons inquiry.Friends of Libby are praying for her . One, Rachel wrote: “Please just come home lib.”Another said: “I just want my best friend back.”Lisa has posted a heartfelt message on her Facebook, and changed her profile picture to one of Libby.She wrote: “One week without her”, with crying emojis.Lisa also thanked the public for their support. title: woman in the window author exposed as liar
story: He has had plenty of struggles, from cancer to nursing his dying mum and a brother lost to suicide.And his book, The Woman In The Window, is so good it sparks a global bidding war, leading to a seven-figure deal and a Hollywood film.It’s even talked of in the same breath as publishing sensations The Girl On The Train and Gone Girl.On its arrival last year, it shoots straight to the top of the New York Times bestseller list, the first debut to do so in  years.Finally, Dan Mallory reveals ­himself as the author behind the pen name on the cover, AJ Finn.Only, like all great stories, there’s a crisis point — and Mallory has just reached his.This week an investigation into the -year-old’s background unearthed some glaring untruths, from lying about deaths in his family to ­earning an Oxford doctorate and, most shockingly, his brain cancer.An unnamed colleague said: “Money and power were important to him, but so was drama and securing people’s sympathies.“If there was a story to tell that would help him, he would tell it.”The damning report in The New Yorker magazine paints a picture of a Talented Mr Ripley figure, a suave and brilliant man who fabricated parts of his le to gain sympathy and further his ego.Indeed, Mallory — who worked in publishing before writing his debut novel — even studied fictional ­fantasist  Ripley at university.On the surface, he is a charming New Yorker, a senior ­editor at publisher William Morrow, which ended up ­buying the rights for a two-book deal for £.million.But one former Morrow colleague even told friends: “There’s this guy in the office who has a Talented Mr Ripley thing going on.”New Yorker journalist Ian Parker found a number of startling anomalies. There was the time Mallory ly bragged about spotting ­potential in crime novel The Cuckoo’s Calling by Robert ­Galbraith while working for ­publisher Little, Brown and Co in London, before it was known to be a pseudonym for Harry Potter author JK Rowling.Then there was a fabrication about working with US comedy actress Tina Fey, and “sexing up” the script for horror film Final Destination while working as an intern, neither of which are true, say the people involved.Poet Craig Raine, who taught English at Oxford, said Mallory’s application to do a PhD there included a moving story about ­caring for his brother Jake, who had cystic fibrosis, and his mother Pamela, who had breast cancer.He said: “At some point, when Dan was nursing her, he got a brain tumour, which he didn’t tell her about, because he thought it would be upsetting to her.“And evidently, that sort of cleared up. And then she died. The brother had already died.”Raine also believed Mallory had written that his dad John had also died. In fact, all three are alive.Pamela was treated for breast ­cancer when Mallory was a teenager.Her husband John, a former Wall Street banker, confirmed she had been “next to death”. However last year she joined Mallory on a book-promoting tour of New Zealand.Mallory does have a Masters degree from Oxford but he never completed his doctorate, even though he had signed emails from “Dr Mallory” in his second year. The story about the brain tumour came up again in , while working at Little, Brown.He wore a baseball cap, which many assumed was to cover hair loss from chemotherapy, and said he had less than a decade to live.Not long afterwards, he left Little, Brown. The New Yorker claimed Mallory’s boss discovered he had lied about a job offer at a rival company, which resulted in a promotion and pay rise to keep him at Little, Brown.“Once that fell away, then you think, ‘Is he really ill ’”, said one ­suspicious colleague.Two years later, in February , work friends in the UK received an email written by Dan’s brother, Jake, saying Mallory was due to have ­surgery to remove a tumour.US colleagues received a similar email, about the removal of a tumour from his spine, the following day. But some recipients had suspicions about the writing style and concluded they may have come from Mallory himself.Mallory has admitted that he lied about having cancer, saying it was easier than talking about his mental health.He said: “It is the case that on numerous occasions in the past, I have stated, implied or allowed others to believe that I was afflicted with a physical malady instead of a psychological one: Cancer, specically.”Apologising for his actions, he wrote: “I was utterly terried of what people would think of methey knew — that they’d conclude I was defective in a way that I should be able to correct, or worse still, that they wouldn’t believe me. Dissembling seemed the easiest path.”He has since spoken openly about his problems, including bipolar ­disorder, and said he chose to use a pen name because he did not want his publishing experience to affect his chance of getting a deal.He added: “I am not especially interested in author’s bios. I am ­buying their novel, not their memoir.I view it as a sign of respect to not want to know too much.”As his own stories unravel, Mallory will surely be hoping his readers think the same.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: organ donor saved five lives

title: brexit tories new policies
story: Where are the radical plans to sort the housing crisis, or soaring crime  Or to lower taxes, as Tories always should New NHS cash aside, what can Theresa May’s Government boast about after nearly three years of Brexit paralysis Its unhinged war on our sugar intake Its scandalous suffocation at birth of the fracking industry Sneaking through new taxes on the dead The Tories need a brand new offer to voters, and fast.BecauseBrexit is ever sorted, they will suddenly require answers to Corbyn’s armoury of policies.Most of those are ruinous throwbacks to the s. title: army deployed apache arctic circle
story: The “battle winning” Army helicopters have been operating in Norway, which borders Russia, for the last five weeks. And days ago conducted live fire drills for the first time - in temperatures plunging to - degrees.Brigadier Mike Keating, operations officer for Joint Helicopter Command, hailed the “extraordinary” chopper, saying: “We’ve got a world-class capability in the hands of the British Army.“That’s exactly why we brought it here, to learn those lessons and prove to ourselves and any adversaries out there that no matter where trouble might face us, we are prepared to go and face it.“Whether it’s in the deserts of Afghanistan or in the freezer of the Arctic Circle.The Apache Helicopter sends a psychological message to any potential enemy, to any foe that’s out there – just look at it – it bristles with weapon systems that are in many ways unique.”Last week The Sun travelled to Bardufoss, , miles from the UK and  miles inside the Arctic Circle, to witness Apaches from  Sqn, Army Air Corps, in action.British troops have been coming here for cold weather warfare training for  years, but now Top Brass have sent Apaches to the region in a bid to bolster NATOs Northern flank amid Russian aggression.The move comes as the Arctic is set to become a key new battleground as global warming opens new shipping routes and access to oil reserves beneath the ice.As a result both NATO allies and Russia have ramped up training and bought extra kit for the expected fight for control of the region.Now Britain has added Apache into the mix, armed with its mm canon, Hellfire missiles and rockets. They built up a ferocious reputation in the furnace of Helmand and Top Brass confirmed they are proving equally devastating in the Earth’s freezer.Next week Prince Harry – a former Apache pilot and current Captain General of the Royal Marines –will visit the region to witness the training, code named Exercise Clockwork.Brig Keating, called the addition of Apaches a “step change” adding: “Whether you are Royal Marine, a parachute Regiment soldier, whether you are an infantry soldier in the British Army, it is a game changer.“It brings a huge amount of firepower and it emboldens our ground forces as well. Andthat is sending a message to a whole range of adversaries, then that is the right thing to be doing.”Army Air Corps pilot Captain Ash – whose identity we are not printing for security reasons – said: “It was battle wining in Afghanistan, and we’ve come out to Norway and it is performing better than expected, so I fully expect to be a battle-winning aircraft in this environment as well.“The weather changes very quickly here, we have to be prepared to survive in the environment as wellwe have to go down on the ground.“I think it’s been a huge learning curve for everyone. It’s been amazing, it’s been great fun, we’re inside the Arctic Circle, flying the world’s best attack helicopter, what more could you want.”Operating in these harsh conditions is an almost impossible challenge. Troops must be forward based to remote locations ready to rearm and refuel the Apaches, living in tents buried in snow in the freezing conditions.The temperature beneath the rotor “disc” downwash is even colder but soldiers cannot wear their heavy mittens as they need to use their finders to load rounds and operate complex machinery. It means working time is massively reduced.Meanwhile the pilots have to contend with turbulence rushing up and down the mountains, freak snow storms, and terrain blanketed in white making it tough to see changes on the ground.They have all been trained in survival methodsthey have to go down in the snow miles from rescue.Brig Keating, said: “We can’t fly anywhere in the world without our boys and girls on the ground helping us. They are as crucial a part of this endeavour as the pilots who sit in the front of this aircraft.“And I take my hats off to them, what we are asking them to do, the conditions we are asking them to operate under, are quite incredible. To a person, they are brilliant people, they are thriving out here, they love the challenge, this is really hard soldiering out here.“If you can soldier here, you can soldier anywhere. We need to master this environment, and we know thatthe requirement to come fight here ever comes up we can do it.“To get that aircraft lting off, bristling with weaponry to go and do what it needs to do at the far end in an amazing achievement. It’s the boys and girls who pull it together and are prepared to face those conditions out there and deliver.”Top Brass said this training will be repeated over the coming months and years so troops on the ground can rely on attack choppers in any potential future war in the snow.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit delay local election wipe out
story: The ongoing deadlock with the EU has led many to expect the Article  exit talks will have to be extended beyond the March  deadline.But local government bosses and Cabinet ministers have warned No as well as the Tory party’s chairman that its vote at the council polls on May  will be decimatedthey are seen to have broken the key Brexit promise.That gives the PM just a five week extra window to wrap up Brexit and pass all necessary new laws, and  weeks in total from now.The Conservatives most senior councillor, Lord Porter – who chairs the Local Government Association, told The Sun: “If we’re not out by the time of the elections, we’re going to get kicked.It won’t be good for us.“It will also hit turnout, as people will be put off politics altogether.“Brandon Lewis has been made very aware of this.”A Cabinet minister also warned about the dire consequences of delaying Brexit beyond July , which would mean the UK would almost certainly be forced to hold fresh MEP elections along with the rest of Europe.The senior minister told The Sun: “The new European Parliament takes it seats on July , sowe’re not out by then we’ll have to blow £m on holding new elections here for it.“Our councillors are telling us that voters would punish us hard at the ballot box in May for this.So extending that long is untenable.”During meetings in Brussels on Thursday, it emerged Mrs May told EU chiefs she would not ask to extend Article , despite the fast approaching exit deadline.This year’s local elections are being held almost everywhere across England, outside of London.A total of  English local councils are up for grabs, as well as six directly elected mayors in England, and all  local councils in Northern Ireland.Almost all were last contested in  on the same day as the General Election, which David Cameron’s Tories won.Successor LordKerslake said Britain is heading for years of wrangling with Brussels.The new warnings came as former top mandarin Lord O’Donnell became the latest senior figure to urge the Brexit deadline be extended.The former Cabinet Secretary to three Prime Ministers between  and  wrote in the Evening Standard: “Are we going to follow a Norwegian model or one from Singapore, Turkey, Switzerland or Albania “The truth is we do not know and it is, I am afraid to say, irresponsible for any government to even contemplate embarking on such a perilous journey as Brexit without giving us a clearer idea of the eventual destination.”Next week the Commons could back a motion drawn up by senior Labour MP Yvette Cooper to delay Britain’s leaving datewe’re heading for No Deal.But evenMPs do vote for the controversial amendment, every single EU country would have the right to veto it.French officials have warned that they won’t approve a delay unless the UK has a coherent plan to use the extra time.A source told Reuters: “Fundamentally, we oppose an extension without a plan. That’s clear. We won’t accept it.”The official added that a delay would only be acceptableBritain wanted time “to build a new political solution”.Where are the radical plans to sort the housing crisis, or soaring crime  Or to lower taxes, as Tories always should New NHS cash aside, what can Theresa May’s Government boast about after nearly three years of Brexit paralysis Its unhinged war on our sugar intake Its scandalous suffocation at birth of the fracking industry  Sneaking through new taxes on the dead The Tories need a brand new offer to voters, and fast. BecauseBrexit is ever sorted, they will suddenly require answers to Corbyn’s armoury of policies.Most of those are ruinous throwbacks to the s. But every day they are out there unchallenged, they gain traction.To some voters any plan — even from Marxist extremists — is more enticing than a listless Government bereft of ideas.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The riled Taoiseach was also accused of contradicting himself ahead of the PM’s arrival in the Irish capital for dinner with him.Mr Varadkar snapped at suggestions that Mrs May is trying to go behind his back to Brussels chiefs and enforce legal changes to the controversial Irish backstop to ensure it is only temporary.He declared: “I am the European Union when it comes to these matters. story: NewsEmiliano Sala investigator makes offer to pilot David Ibbotsons familyEXCLUSIVE: David Mearns, who led the mission to find the footballers body, says he hasnt had contact with the pilots familyShareCommentsByAdam Aspinall:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror sport video tributes-laid-memory-emiliano-sala-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe investigator who found Emiliano Salas body has offered hope to the family of the missing pilot saying he would come to their aidhe could. David Mearns, the crack maritime investigator hired by the Sala family to find the wreckage of his doomed plane, said he would treat David Ibbotsons family just the same as Salasthey made contact with him. He told The Mirror: “I came to the aid of the Sala family on a voluntary basis because they needed help.  “We are just a loose group of people who came together to do this because it was the right thing to do. “If the Ibbotson family came to us I would treat them in exactly the same way as anyone  and see what we could do. I have had not contact with the Ibbotson family. “There is still a body to be found and a plane wreck to recover but the private search came to an end once the wreckage was discovered and the AAIB took over. “With the weather conditions out there right now it is not possible to continue the search at the moment so it is too early to say what will happen.”   On Thursday night police confirmed the body found in the plane wreckage in the English Channel is that of Cardf City striker Emiliano Sala, . But the body of -year-old Ibbotson is yet to be found. The day before it emerged an unidentied body - now known to be Sala - was brought off ship, Geo Ocean III, on a stretcher and transferred to a private ambulance before being taken to Dorset Police and the local coroner. The plane was flying from Nantes, France, the home of Salas former team, to Cardf on January , when it crashed into the sea with the new poundmillion signing and pilot David Ibbotson inside. Shortly after the news was confirmed, Cardf City released a statement on their website which read: “We offer our most heartfelt sympathies and condolences to the family of Emiliano.   “He and David will forever remain in our thoughts.” Salas sister Romina posted a picture stood on the pitch at Nantes, arms out either side as he looked up to the sky. Her emotional tribute to her brother said: “Your soul in my soul will shine forever, illuminating the time of my existence. I love you”. Earlier on Thursday Romina revealed she had adopted her brothers dog Nala. Today Salas family also appealed for Ibbotsons body to be found. They said in a statement: “We would like to thank you for all your signs of affection and support in what is the most painful time of our lives. “Seeing the whole world mobilized to support us in our research has been infinitely precious help. Thanks to you, we are now able mourn our son and brother. “Our thoughts got to David Ibbotson and his family, hoping the authorities will do their best to find him.” David Ibbotsons family were unavailable for comment today.

story: NewsBrexit: Government cancels contract with shipless ferry company Seaborne FreightSeaborne Freight was awarded a contract worth £.million to provide extra capacity for transport as part of Brexit contingency planning designed to ease the pressure on DoverShareCommentsByAine Fox:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsSeaborne Freight was contracted to operate out of Ramsgate "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe government has cancelled a ferry contract it awarded to a company with no ships.The pound.million deal with Seaborne Freight sealed by Transport Secretary Chris Grayling attracted widespread criticism. The firm was due to help provide extra capacity as part of contingency planning for a no-deal Brexit , which could heap pressure on Dover.The Department for Transport said it had decided to terminate the contract after Irish company Arklow Shipping, which had backed Seaborne Freight, stepped away from the deal. A DfT spokeswoman said: Following the decision of Seaborne Freights backer, Arklow Shipping, to step back from the deal, it became clear Seaborne would not reach its contractual requirements with the Government. We have therefore decided to terminate our agreement. The Government is already in advanced talks with a number of companies to secure additional freight capacity - including through the port of Ramsgate - in the event of a no-deal Brexit. Mr Grayling last month defended the Seaborne Freight contract, insisting it was not a risk.

title: brian reade twisted words starved
story: NewsopinionBrian Reade: Twisted words and starved of benefits... welcome to real hellThis country has been locked in a state of arrested ­development for the past three years as all political energy has been spent on failing to deliver an imaginary freedom from invented tyrantsShareCommentsByBrian Reade:,  FEB Newsopinionthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video mirroronthestreet-campaign-tent-city-leeds-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIve never been to hell although I have stood in a Zara s queue for an hour. It’s not a place I want to visit, shyespecially now Donald Tusk assures us it could soon be home to the likes of Nigel Farage, Jacob Rees-Mogg and Michael Gove. Imagine the dficulty in choosing which one to withhold your pee fromthey were all on fire  Of course, the Eurocrat’s damning words about the people who “promoted Brexit without even a sketch of a plan how to carry it out safely” have been twisted to make it sound like he wants to give a one-way ticket to Satanville to all . million leave voters. But there’s nothing new in that. Twisted words, half-truths and outright lies are the weapons that have kept this country locked in a state of arrestedshy development for the past three years as all political energy has been spent on failing to deliver an imaginary freedom from invented tyrants.   Meanwhile, the issues that affect the lives of the vast majority living in the real world are ignored, leaving the weakest to go to the wall. Hence the mass use of foodbanks becoming an acceptable part of le in the world’s sixth biggest economy. Who could have read The Mirror’s shock report on homelessness across Britain without feeling immensely saddened and angry  I was one of  reporters who spoke to some of the thousands of people forced to live on our freezing streets every night. The reasons behind their soaring numbers are complex but the scourge is beatable. And surely every rich and civilised country wants it beaten  But what happens when your country is made poorer and less civilised due to devoting its resources to solving one political party’s insoluble dilemma  On Wednesday, the Commons rose at .pm instead of the usual .pm due to MPs running out of things to debate. As Shadow Commons Leader, Valerie Vaz, said: “This shyGovernment has no vision, no new ideas and crucially no legislation to fill the parliamentary timetable.” In the past three months alone, the Cabinet Office has handed pound. million to outside consultancy firms helping them with Brexit. How many people could that have taken off our streets    Most local councils are doing their best to meet the homeless crisis head-on, but when your funding from Westminster has been decimated it’s left to volunteers, charities and the goodwill of the public to take up the slack. Who could have failed to be angry looking at the photo of the skeletal -year-old Stephen Smith, who, despite having multiple shydebilitating illnesses, weighing six stone, and barely able to walk, was denied benefits by this Government and deemed fit for work.   It was only when he went for free advice at the CASA community centre in Liverpool, where volunteer advisers appealed and won his case, that he received the benefits that kept him alive. There was a typically rabid response from the right in this country to Tusk’s remarks about those who sold Brexit without a trace of a plan deserving a place in hell. But many of us agree with him. Because they are the dangerous ideologues behind the three years of political paralysis that has made le hell for those who least deserve it.

title: gravediggers strike helped put final
story: NewsGravediggers strike that helped put the final nail in the coffin of union powerDuring Labours winter of discontent, striking gravediggers were demonised in headlines flashed around the worldShareCommentsByPaul Routledge:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsIan Lowes was the gravediggers’ GMB convenor at the time "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThey were condemned from the pulpit, denounced in Parliament and vilied in the media for not going to work. Their job was to dig graves and operate the crematorium for the people of Liverpool. But for  anxious days, they were on strike in the Winter of Discontent that paralysed the nation and cost Labour political power in . The gravediggers’ walkout was demonised in headlines like “Now They Won’t Let Us Bury Our Dead!”. Families were split and violence flared on Merseyside in the dispute – merely a microcosm of a national confrontation between Labour premier “Sunny Jim” Callaghan and the labour movement. Such was the furore that  years later, survivors of the industrial action cannot bring themselves to talk about it openly.   One man who can is Ian Lowes, , the gravediggers’ GMB convenor at the time and still a union activist. He defends the strike. “It was ‘enough is enough’ by low-paid workers who were treated like dogs.” But he promises: “Never again.” The diggers’ down-shovels was a long time coming. Denis Healey, Labour’s Iron Chancellor, decreed a % pay rise limit for all workers in summer . At a secret meeting that autumn in his Sussex farmhouse, TUC leaders – among them David Basnett, leader of the cemetery workers’ union – warned him that, after years of wage restraint, they could not hold their members back.   Pay curbs were rejected at Labour’s annual conference, and the floodgates opened when striking Ford workers won a % pay rise. A tanker drivers’ walkout triggered a national fuel emergency before % increases were conceded. Public service unions swtly took up the cudgels and, on January , , staged a National Day of Action in support of a pound-a-week minimum wage, practically double the gravediggers’ money. In numbers, this was the biggest stoppage since the General Strike of . Eventually, the year lost ,, working days to stoppages. Stre came to Merseyside when GMB shop stewards representing , workers employed by Liverpool City Council met to plan a follow-up. “The national leaders had lost control,” says Ian. “So we decided to go for selective action, bringing out key workers and putting a financial levy on everybody . Binmen carried on working but we closed tips, so the rubbish piled up.”   In the Parks and Gardens department, eight crematorium workers and about  gravediggers were called out on a show of hands. This was the s, before Tory labour laws demanded pre-strike secret ballots. The walkout was solid. Pickets weren’t needed at the city’s big sites like Allerton Cemetery – where we’re speaking today – and the adjoining Springwood Crematorium. The levy meant the strikers enjoyed virtual take-home pay. It could have gone on indefinitely, like some of the walkouts by council workers that left London’s Leicester Square a mountain of uncollected refuse, and half the country’s hospitals on emergency admissions only as NHS manual workers joined the dispute.   Leaders of the Liberal-run city council begged the men to go back, the chief executive anticipating media malice with a plea, “Even in war they stop to bury the dead”. An irate GMB official came to Liverpool and ordered the men resume work, prompting a predictable Scouse raspberry. Hostility went off the Richter scale. Inevitably, Tory leader Margaret Thatcher condemned the walkout, sensing electoral opportunity. In the Commons, Anthony Steen, Tory MP for Liverpool Wavertree, called it “repugnant, an outrage to human decency” causing great personal distress to the bereaved. Some  bodies were awaiting burial or cremation, embalmed and stored in a disused factory in Speke, he told MPs. “This strike offends against the dignity of man, and is a horrying example of man’s indference and inhumanity to the dead,” he declared.  This was the MP later to find fame for claiming pound, expenses for his country home in Devon, where he moved after losing his Scouse seat. And a vicar shared this apocalyptic vision: “When gravediggers will allow corpses to mount up rather than carry out their duty, I detect the undermshyining of the whole structure of society.” Duty  For the men it was a job of work, carried out for -odd quid a week in all weathers, without protective clothing. They were not even allowed into the canteen for their break. A dumper truck came round with the tea and they ate their snap round an open hole. Ian insists: “This was all about a group of low-paid people fighting to try to get a better deal. They had a right to withdraw their labour but, when they did, the consequences were terrible.” As working-class men in communities, it was obvious strikers’ identities would be known. One was attacked in a pub and taken to AE, where it is said he was left for hours by NHS staff, even though they were in dispute, too. One whose mother died is still not speaking to the family. There were threatening letters and verbal abuse. In fact, I understand some cremations were secretly taking place at Springwood of bodies that could not be embalmed. They were held in the evening, by unpaid volunteers. In the second week of the walkout, they gathered to take stock. Enough really was enough – of the strike. The action was hurting ordinary people, not the government. They voted to go back after  tumultuous days in the eye of a media storm. Propaganda damage had done its worst in this corner of militancy, but the wider dispute did not end. Council workers struck, and unofficial strikes by ambulance staff and other public service workers continued until late February, when % pay rises were granted and Healey signed a peace treaty with the TUC. As a show of political unity, it was too little, too late. Jim Callaghan had ducked a general election in September . Labour was then five points in the lead in opinion polls, but by the end of the Winter of Discontent the Tories were  ahead. They were helped by complacent Callaghan, who ed from a conference in the sunny Caribbean and didn’t quite say to reporters at Heathrow, “Crisis, what crisis ” But the headlines did, and that’s what mattered in a nation on the cusp of radical political change. “Britain Isn’t Working” ads and TV broadcasts for the May election showed footage of rubbish piled in the streets, picketed hospitals and locked cemeteries. Swept into power on an anti-union ticket, Thatcher enacted laws that would have made the gravediggers’ dispute unlawful. Some say the unions dug their own grave. Does Ian, a one-time member of the hard-left Militant Tendency, think it could happen again  “In the last  years, this is the only time there has been a dispute in the cemeteries of Liverpool. There have been issues, but they have been resolved without strike action. My answer is no.” That might come as a relief to the  workers who still tend the city’s six cemeteries. title: ibiza club rep reveals life
story: NewsIbiza club rep reveals le of sun, sex and booze isnt all its cut out to beJack Cremin, from Birmingham, quit his job and booked a one-way ticket - but his summer wasnt without its challengesShareCommentsByAshley Preece:,  FEB NewsJack Cremin, right, and his best mate Jake taking time out in Ibiza"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former club rep has lted the lid on what le is like in Ibiza - and its not for the faint hearted. Jack Cremin, from Birmingham, quit his job in recruitment and booked a one-way flight to the Balearic Islands - and spent months enjoying boat parties, beers and scenes of pure barminess. He had always wanted to work at Europes party capital.Jack, , told Birmingham Live : I’d always wanted to do a season somewhere and, the previous year, I’d been to Ibiza three times.I love the place so, when I got a bit sick of recruitment and I was looking where, I thought it was the perfect opportunity to go and do it. Jack, then , went about working a five-month season from early June to October. But it didnt start the way he had hoped.   The season usually starts out there in May, he explained, but me and my friend chose to go over a bit later and so we struggled with accommodation. We managed to find a really cheap hostel at the top of the strip for the first three weeks and decided we would go from there. The hostel was awful. There were no windows in most of the rooms, you could hear everything from the strip all night long and there was barely enough room for one person, let alone two. The hell hole was literally something mad like pound for  nights. Jack, though, blew an eye-watering pound, in the first four weeks of being in Ibiza after deciding against getting a job.   But splashing the cash caught up with him and he soon found himself hopping from bed to bed to get some sleep. I decided before I went that I would most likely go for a club rep job, he said. But, with the first couple of weeks being so wild, I didn’t think about looking for work at all. I was too busy enjoying myself. And when it came to the girls, lets say it wasnt hard to find someone to take back. The real problem came when our three-week hostel stay was coming to an end and, with everywhere booked out, we were soon bed hopping or sofa surfing! Jack and his pal stayed on someones sofa for three nights in exchange for paying for a food shop before finally landing a job. And, after going from blowing almost two grand, he was soon noshing on Super Noodles sandwiches and downing cocktails.  We ended up selling boat party tickets, explained Jack, who now works for a fruit and veg company. This was a commission-based role where you would earn ten euro for every ticket sold or  euro for a package deal, which was a boat party and entry to Ocean Beach. This seemed like a good idea at the time but the thought of meeting at am on the promenade every day to debrief and then to walk around in the blistering heat all day soon wore off. Most of our days were spent waking up around  or pm, finding a nice posh hotel swimming pool to relax in pretending we were guests and then either going to an apartment party or trying to swindle together a few euros to go out on the strip. If you were low on money your best bet was to get a ‘Sketamine’ from Ground Zero, which would be five euro for five shots of vodka mixed with lemonade and grenadine to take away the kick, two of these would do the job. After eating like kings for the first six weeks or so, we soon found ourselves living off a diet of tuna and pasta, Super Noodles sandwiches or a ‘workers meal’ from Burger King which would consist of a small burger, fries and a drink for €..  Jack also admitted frequently downing cheap wine before sneaking into the swanky Ocean Beach Club, which is popular among celebrities, music stars and footballers. Its my favourite place in Ibiza but, as many people know, unless you pre-book a bed or are on holiday with plenty of spare cash, there isn’t much point in going, explained Jack. Luckily I found a way around this because one of the girls I know kept getting us in on the guest list. We would usually end up pre-drinking cheap wine to ensure we didn’t have to pay for many drinks when we got in there! Jack drank in well-known bars The Highlander and Soul City and, despite some low points during his time working abroad, he made friends for le and would do it all over again - only to plan it better for next time!  I’d do it againI was out of work, he said, but I’d definitely plan it a lot better. All in all, doing a season was a brilliant experience and I think it taught me a lot. One thing I would say is to make sure you have your accommodation sorted before you get over there!This can usually be done by joining one of the ‘workers groups’ on Facebook .Another little tip is to use these pages to book what are known as ‘workers taxis’ - these will often cost you around half the price of a normal taxi. And, although I would probably say I am maybe a bit too old to do another season, I would highly recommend it for any youngster looking to have a good time. I am also going back in June as I have planned my best friends stag do there!

story: NewsMan flung through air like ragdoll by speeding Audi driver who left him for deadWARNING - UPSETTING CONTENT: Ahmed Yousef is lucky to be alive after being hit by a car driven by Haider Mriza in Normanton, Derby, in November ShareCommentsByNick Reid:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video cctv-appalling-moment-audi-driver-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHorrying footage shows the moment a man was thrown  metres along the road like a ragdoll after being hit by an Audi driver who drove off without stopping. Driver Haider Mirza, , caused le-threatening injuries to victim Ahmed Yousef, who suffered a fractured skull and now has one leg permanently shorter than the other. Shocked witnesses are seen rushing to help Mr Yousef following the crash in Normanton, Derby, in November .The victim was crossing the road when the Audi A with Mirza at the wheel ploughed into him, Derbyshire Live reports.Despite a public appeal, Mirza did not come forward, and evaded police for  months.  Judge Philip Wassall, who presided over the case, handed Mirza a custodial sentence of  months and banned him from driving. He also commended Derbyshire Live and the police for sharing the CCTV footage, as he stated this helped in Mirzas capture. Jailing Mirza, Judge Wassall said: This was appalling. You were in no doubt as to what you had done and you left the scene at an unabated pace. You would have known that the person you hit would be really seriously injured. Looking at the CCTV it is only through luck that Mr Yousef wasnt killed.  You have shown remorse, but I feel that stems from the position you are now in, rather than being genuine. You evaded officers for eleven months while they investigated the incident. The car has never been found and even when you were sent the link to the Derbyshire Live story of the police appeal, you still did not hand yourself in. You have got a bad motoring record, not just before this, but since. You are  years of age and you pleaded guilty in magistrates court. That is the first sign of something positive. You have had some heartfelt references from your family members, but I have to put these into context with what you have done. Mirza was at the wheel when his car hit Mr Yousef at .pm on November .  Derbyshire Live published CCTV footage of the incident and appealed for witnesses to come forward. Laura Pitman, prosecuting, stated that police scanned hours of CCTV footage to find the driver. A witness told police they partially spotted the numberplate of the car during the collision and officers were able to trace it to Mirza. He was arrested in January  and his phone was seized. During an -month investigation, officers found a number of messages sent to his partner which showed he was responsible for the hit-and-run incident. In the messages he had also stated the car had gone.  Mirza was arrested again in December . He appeared before magistrates the same month and pleaded guilty to causing serious injury by dangerous driving, driving without a licence, failing to stop after a collision and using a vehicle with no insurance. Ms Pitman stated that Mr Yousef had been living in the UK since , was working and sending money back to Sudan to care for his mother. She said: Mr Ahmed was in work and was earning money and was sending a portion of it back to his mother in Sudan. At the time, she was very unwell and needed medical treatment. He has lost his home, is on benefits and is practically homeless. A friend of his is letting him stay at his place. He still has regular medical appointments at two hospitals and is still having physiotherapy. He still gets pain in his shoulder and right leg. One of his legs is now shorter than the other.  This accident has had an enormous impact on this gentleman who was simply out to buy credit for his mobile phone so he could call his family. Mr Yousef was in court to see the sentencing and spoke to Derbyshire Live following the case. He said: My le has been ruined, before the accident I had a very nice le and a le to look forward to. I was working, I was happy and content, but now I stopped working because of the accident and now my le is not that good. I am very happy that he got a just sentence. I am still going to hospital and I still have future appointments, this has changed my le. I dont have a say in the future, it is not in my hands or in my control, but I am waiting from the assessments and while I wait for them, I feel my le is not normal. I hope in the future everything will be OK. Detective Sergeant Darren Muggleton, of the serious collision investigation unit, said: We are pleased today after all this time that Mirza has been brought to justice. It has taken a long time to get here because he didnt admit to being the driver until the evidence reached court. We are pleased with the comments the judge made to the seriousness to this offence and the sentence given was appropriate. We released CCTV footage and it is horrendous. Mirza didnt slow down or stop and Mr Yousef was projected into the air. The whole team couldnt believe he survived, he was thrown into the air like a ragdoll. Mr Mirza must have known what had happened and it took months and months of a detailed investigation to establish the suspect. We would like to thank the public who gave us the leads that we needed to track down Mirza. Judge Wassall said: I would like to commend Derbyshire Live for their story which undoubtedly helped witnesses come forward who helped catch the defendant. The court also heard how Mirza had several relevant previous convicitons. In March , he failed to give his name and address after an accident and was handed a -month community order and  hours unpaid work. In August , he was disqualied from driving for  months. In October , he was disqualied from driving for  months for driving without due care and attention, driving without a licence and driving without insurance during for an incident that took place the previous July. Stephen Cobley, mitigating, said: The footage is absolutely shocking. His antecedence doesnt help him at all and there are aggravated feaures. It passes the custody threshld. He has been remorseful and realises what he has done. His family have written several heartfelt character references which show a dferent side to Mirza. He is a prominent figure in the area where he lives and has been helping the homeless. Mirza was handed  months in prison, three years four months, for dangerous driving. He was also disqualied from driving for  months. He was also handed a four month sentence for failing to stop at the scene of an accident. This will run concurrently.

title: uks worst wedding photographers leave
story: NewsUKs worst wedding photographers leave brides devastated over blurry photosDarren and Adele McDonagh who ran Treasured Moments Photography together botched photos for hundreds of married couplesShareCommentsByMark Lister:,  FEB NewsNewlyweds Chantelle and David Maconochie from Chester-le-Street were victims of the fraudster pair "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA wedding photographer couple have left hundreds of brides out of pocket and devastated over blurred snaps of their big day. Newlyweds have been turning to guests’ snaps and ‘selfies’ to salvage memories of their big day. Darren and Adele McDonagh - who ran Treasured Moments Photography - sometimes failed to turn up to capture the happy day, it has been alleged. When they did arrive they are accused of taking blurred images, focused on grooms’ bottoms rather than the brides’ faces and took months to send the pictures -they did at all. Police and Action Fraud are investigating claims the couple conned brides and grooms by promising drones, photo booths, and minute-by-minute capture of the weddings, and pocketed up to pound,.   Chantelle and David Maconochie, of Chester-le-Street, Co Durham, booked Treasured Moments for  June, last year for a romantic white wedding at St Mary’s and St Cuthbert’s Church, in Middle Chair, followed by a reception and party at the Beamish Park Hotel. Mum-of-four Chantelle, , and bus driver Darren, , shelled out pound to book the couple. But only Adele turned up and the newlyweds say she ruined their nuptials by crying and complaining she was depressed and suffering from anxiety over the loss of a baby. Other brides and grooms - more than  couples - have also reportedly complained the McDonaghs blamed hospital appointments, accidents, family bereavements and vandalism for not delivering the promised wedding photos.   Chantelle said: ”When Adele turned up she told me the day was the anniversary of her baby’s death, which put a downer on the day. “She demanded the DJ play the first dance early so she could get home sooner and she was asking me what poses I wanted to do. “She was crying all the time and missed our first kiss and mucked up me walking down the aisle. “For our first dance all she captured was photos of Darren’s butt and when we eventually got the pictures, after months of waiting and complaining, many were out focus and unusable in a wedding album.”   The couple were forced to drive from Chester-le-Street to Leeds to pick up a USB stick with the unedited photographs. Hundreds of disgruntled couples have taken to social media to expose the McDonaghs and warn other brides not to use them - but scores of newlyweds have been left out of pocket and relying on friends’ mobile photos as memories of their wedding day. The McDonaghs, of Leeds, West Yorks, have refunded some brides and have finally delivered images, but many have been left wanting. They have claimed to have gone bankrupt, but there are no court records to back up this. When confronted at home they refused to comment.

Sabrina McCarl and partner Marco Simoes were left devastated when severely disabled son Tiago McCarl-Simoes died from pneumonia in . Despite previously working in the UK, Marco - a Portuguese national - has been refused Universal Credit on residency grounds. And Sabrinas monthly allowance leaves the couple and their surviving son, Ruben, with around pound a week to live on, Birmingham Live reports. The couple say their family risks being split up - as former construction site worker Marco, who has suffered from tumours in his right hand, is considering moving back to Portugal despite having been in the country for  years. Both of them have suffered from depression after Tiago’s death on October , .  Marco, , said: “We’ve tried to do everything the correct way, but Universal Credit is the biggest mess ever. “I was receiving benefits as normal as our sons joint carer, he was very, very ill until he passed away. I’d also worked and paid tax in the UK in construction jobs removing asbestos. “After our son passed away we moved houses and I was told to apply for Universal Credit. I showed them all the documents and paperwork, right down to my NHS number, but they decided I wasnt entitled to anything, even though everything was fine before. “Its been a nightmare. We only survive on my partners money, we cant afford clothes and I haven’t had pound in my wallet for the last year.  “Im trying to find work and waiting to see what happens with Brexit but its looking like I’ll have no choice but toto Portugal and leave my family behind.” Marco, who previously claimed Employment and Support Allowance, has needed surgery on his hand to remove the tumours but it constantly swells up and he will need further treatment as well as monitoring to ensure the growths are not cancerous. Sabrina, , has doctor’s notes for depression and anxiety as the basis for her Universal Credit claim that amounts to around pound a month before bills, which include rent, gas and electricity at the housing association home where they live with their six-year-old son Ruben. “By the time we’ve paid the bills we barely have pound to pound a week to spare, and much of that is taken up with bus fares,” said Sabrina. “I’ve had to turn to family to borrow money and to foodbanks.  “We don’t care about ourselves, we just want to give our son the best start in le. “We’ve told them about our bereavement and how we have struggled since but it’s made no dference, they just don’t take into account your needs.” A spokeswoman for the Department for Work and Pensions said: “Ms McCarl receives more than pound a month in Universal Credit, including housing and child support. “We have an obligation to support people who are fully resident in the UK. Mr Simoes has not provided evidence of the right to reside in the UK and therefore is not eligible to receive Universal Credit. This decision has been upheld after review.”

title: young man 22 slashed across
story: NewsYoung man, , slashed across face in random attack - but has amazing responseWARNING: GRAPHIC IMAGES: The horric incident in Manchester put Luke Evans professional boxing career in jeopardyShareByPete BainbridgeAndrew Bardsley:,  FEB NewsLuke Evans, , was left for dead after he was attacked by a gang of yobs "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A young man who was slashed across his face by a gang of thugs has been praised for his amazing response to his attackers. Luke Evans, , was left gashed and bloodied after a night out in Manchester, suffering deep wounds to his face.However the heroic boxer was praised by a judge for urging his attacker and accomplices to move away from a le of crime.Manchester Evening News reports that the attack initially put his promising professional boxing career in jeopardy.Thankfully Mr Evans has since recovered and is back in the ring, but he has been left with physical as well as mental scarring. On Friday, the gang of youths involved in the attack were sentenced at Manchester Crown Court. Speaking to the M.E.N after the court hearing, Luke said: My message to those kids is its not too late to turn your lives around. What youve done is wrong, but its not too late. Im sure deep down you have potential to go on and do something good with your lives.   After the attack I was very angry and distressed. It really ruined my le at the time. Kne crime is a big problem and I feel its my responsibility to be a role model for kids who need motivation. I can help them as a sportsman, rather than hold a grudge or want revenge. During the court hearing, Mr Evans was lauded for offering to help his attackers, and for encouraging them to stay away from crime. The -year-old boy who slashed Mr Evans to the face was sentenced to four-and-a-half years in a young offenders institution, after pleading guilty to counts of wounding with intent and possessing an offensive weapon. The M.E.N. appealed for the judge to lt reporting restrictions on the youths, but the judge rejected their application. A -year-old boy and a -year-old boy both received two year youth rehabilitation orders, which includes a curfew and supervision. They both pleaded guilty to counts of violent disorder and possessing an offensive weapon. Trey Millward, now , of Robinia Close, Eccles, received a two year community order, including  rehabilitation activity requirement days,  hours unpaid work and a three month curfew. He admitted one count of violent disorder. Prosecutor Andrew MacIntosh told the court that Mr Evans had been enjoying a night out in Eccles town centre with his girlfriend on August , . Later that night they went to McDonalds for some food, where they came across the youths. Mr Evans said that the youths seemed to be weighing him up.   After the pair left McDonalds, words were exchanged. Mr Evans said he would fight them one on one, but not in public. One of the youths was said to reply: We dont use our fists, we use our weapons. Later one of the youths was attacked by another man, and a scuffle broke out. The brawl spread to near the bus station in Church Street, at about .am, when other men and women also became involved in the altercation. As the violence continued, one youth ran at Mr Evans armed with a bladed weapon, slashing him to the face. He sustained two deep cuts, which as well as being serious threatened his boxing career, with the fear that the wounds could re-openhe got in the ring. The other youths and Millward were all involved in lower level confrontations, and most were later identied from CCTV footage. The boy who stabbed Mr Evans at first claimed he had been in bed at the time of the attack. His barrister Ian McMeekin said that his parents believed he was revising, and that he had sneaked out of the house. Mr McMeekin said the evening started out as a good natured night out, before Mr Evans sustained his staggeringly horric injuries.   The barrister described Mr Evans as a heroic victim, due to his conduct after being attacked. The court heard that Mr Evans posted on social media, offering to speak with his attackers. Mr McMeekin said: Hebravely said that he would happily speak to the offenders that caused him those injuries, and told them what it was they they had done, and encouraged them to take violence off the streets. It reflects very well on Mr Evans, Judge Alan Conrad QC said. Sentencing, the judge told the four defendants: Its clear to me that this was group violence, involving the carrying and use of weapons. The four of you were all concerned in dferent ways.   You were all ready to take part in this shocking incident where members of the public passed through the town centre at night. Addressing the -year-old who attacked Mr Evans, the judge added: You were given a bladed weapon and you ran towards Luke Evans, slashing at him, causing him awful injuries. The effect of the attack was very serious, both physically and psychologically. Luke added: Its been really dficult for me, both physically and mentally its been really tough. Ive had counselling and without the support of the people round me I wouldnt be where I am today. I want to thank my partner, plus my training team Ricky Hatton, Blain Younis and Mike Jackson. Theyve all helped me so much. Luke has won each of his three bouts since his comeback last June and is now eyeing a first belt.
