either theor the former employees in future, as requested by the newspaper.In his judgment, the judge said lawyers representing thehad said Sir Philiprsquos ldquounlawful conduct was ldquosufficiently serious to engage the public interest, including as it does unwanted contact of a sexual nature general sexual harassment racist language and intimidation and bullying many amounting to criminal offences, and all having serious consequences for employees in particular for their health and wellbeing.

title: new-scotland-canada-partnership-to-support-social-enterprise
story: The Social Enterprise Academy , which provides learning and development for the sector in Scotland, has launched a new partnership with the Canadian Community Economic Development Networksupported by Torontorsquos Learning Enrichment Foundation and the Scottish Government.The collaboration will involve sharing expertise and skills relating to social enterprises ndash businesses focused on creating positive change by reinvesting profits and finding innovative new business models.Ms Sturgeon announced the partnership on a visit to West Neighbourhood House, a community organisation in downtown Toronto, on Friday, the second day of her two-day visit to Canada.FM @NicolaSturgeon opened the Toronto Stock Exchange with @scotent and @GillianDoc pic ABzYjPmdash First MinisterFebruary , She said: ldquoScotland and Canada are already known worldwide as social enterprise nations. Through this exciting partnership, we will be able to share our collective skills and expertise to support people tackling social and environmental challenges in communities at home and around the globe.ldquoIn Scotland, our expertise has been developed through a series of initiatives ndash such as hosting the Social Enterprise World Forum, our -year Social Enterprise Strategy, and funding for a specialist business support service for social enterprises.ldquoBy working together to exchange knowledge and promote business models that contribute to the common good, we can take further steps to improve the lives of those in our countries and further afield.Claire Wilson, head of the SEA Global Learning Lab, said CCEDNet is an ldquoexciting new addition to our international network of partners.She added: ldquoWe look forward to seeing how we can work together to support communities across Canada.Mike Toye, executive director for CCEDNet, said: ldquoWe are pleased to partner with SEA International to accelerate the growth of inclusive and sustainable organisations and communities across Canada and around the world.On Thursday evening Ms Sturgeon officially opened thenew Scottish Government office in Ottawa,as she hosted a Scotland is Now reception in the Canadian capital.During her two-day visit to Canada she has been carrying outtrade and culture engagements in Ottawa and Toronto, which includedopening the Toronto Stock Exchange.Earlier in the week she carried out engagements in the USA on a tour which started on Monday.

title: greeces-parliament-backs-nato-admission-for-macedonia
story: Politicians late on Friday voted - to back the Nato protocol that must now also be approved by all other alliance members.The Greek vote means the former Yugoslav republic will now formally change its name to North Macedonia.That settles a dispute of the countryrsquos name which Greece saw as a potential threat to its own northern region of Macedonia.Greek opposition parties said the agreement made too many concessions to Macedonia.ldquoI would like to again welcome North Macedonia, a country that is friendly toward Greece, a country that must be a supporter, and not an opponent, of our efforts to establish safety, stability, and cooperation in the wider region, Greek prime minister Alexis Tsipras told parliament shortly before the vote.Today is a historic day. All #NATO Allies have signed the Accession Protocol with ##, which will bring more security  prosperity to the whole region. I look forward to the day when  flags will fly outside NATO HQ. pic trPtvsnMDmdash Jens StoltenbergFebruary , Western countries strongly backed the deal between Greece and Macedonia, after the countryrsquos bid to join Nato had been shelved for a decade and amid European concerns over Russiarsquos vocal opposition to the alliancersquos expansion further into the Balkans.ldquoClearly it is in Greecersquos interest to promote a European course for all its neighbours, not just for North Macedonia mdash and notthe influence of third forces in the neighbourhood, with dferent aspirations and pursuits, Mr Tsipras said.

title: gusty-saturday-as-storm-erik-brings-wet-and-windy-weather
story: Gusts of mph are expected on Saturday, as Erik batters much of the country for a second day.The stormrsquos strongest recorded gust on Friday was  mph at Capel Curig, in Wales, the Met Office said.Footage showed aBritish Airways planeforced to abandon its initial landing at Heathrow airport after strong winds put the aircraft off-balance seconds before it was about to touch down.Strong winds will lead to some dficult driving conditions on Saturday morning, especially across northern England #StormErik pic oTteLxHCtmdash Met OfficeFebruary , Also on Friday a tree fell on to a double-decker bus in Dorset, but no injuries were reported.A weather warning for wind on Saturday has been extended to cover most of the UK, while inScotland heavy rain is expected into the afternoon, with a risk of flooding in some parts, the Met Office said.Much of the country will see strong winds and rain showers, some mixed with hale and becoming thundery, meteorologist Alex Burkill said.ldquoItrsquos going to be another very windy one, particularly across northern England, Northern Ireland, southern Scotland and northern Wales. title: pedestrian-45-was-walking-along-the-a823
story: The -year-old was walking along the carriageway of the A between the M and Queensferry Road near Dunfermline today.Police said he was struck by a red DAF lorry at .am and pronounced dead at the scene.Sergeant Dominic Doyle of the Road Policing Unit said: "We are carrying out an investigation to establish the full circumstances and my thoughts are with the family of the man who died."We believe that he had been walking along the road towards Dunfermline but are keen to hear from anyone who was travelling in the area and might have seen him before the collision, or anyone  who may have witnessed the incident itself."A Royal Mail spokesman said: "We are aware of the tragic events that occurred in the Fe area on Saturday morning."Our thoughts and condolences are with the families and friends of those involved."We are assisting the relevant authorities and cannot comment further while the investigation is under way."Contact Police Scotland on .

title: craig ascends bennachie 100 times
story: A Kemnay man ascended Bennachie  times in just one year.Craig Thomson completed the achievement on Sunday, December , .His friend, Ross Henderson, joined Craig on the milestone expedition.Ross said: “I met Craig back in  and a few months after, he spoke about wanting to do Bennachie  times in a year.“The main motivation behind this was the memory of a friend of his, Malcolm, who died of Neuofibromatosis.“Malcolm succombed to the condition shortly after he and Craig had completed an ascent of Bennachie so it is entirely fitting that he should complete such a challenge.”“I quite often saw Craig’s car heading out towards Bennachie on many an occasion, sometimes when it was dark.“I did join him on a few expeditions out on the hill, one of them we timed well as we ed to the car park when it was dusky.“I hadn’t heard much from Craig until a few days before Christmas when he sent me a text askingI wanted to join him for the th ascent.“On the day a few of us met up at the back of Bennachie car park, there were  of us and three dogs so an excellent turnout.“He handed us all a program for the day which contained a written discription of his previous ascents and how he had built up to the full .“In  he managed  and in  he reached  and then stopped counting as it was getting late in the year.”The group set off and after an hour or so they had reached the summit of Oxen Craig, Bennachie’s highest peak.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: inspectors praise north east nursery
story: Education inspectors have expressed confidence in the ongoing improvements being made at Rothienorman Pre-School Nursery.A recent visit led to the village hall facility being described as a “welcome and nurturing environment” and Inspectors said children were “happy, enthusiastic, and developing confidence”.Key strengths included a “dedicated team” which inspectors said have developed positive relationships and a “strong sense of community”.But the nursery has been asked to improve in certain areas, including increased use of national guidance to develop a “robust and rigorous approach to self-evaluation”. Inspectors said this will enable practitioners to identy what is working well and what needs to improve.They also want to see development of approaches to assessment and planning to help improve the quality of learning experiences and provide “greater depth and challenge” for all children.Improvements are also being sought in the development of practitioners’ knowledge and understanding of how to support children’s early language and mathematical thinking.Inspectors are confident that the setting has the capacity to continue to improve and will make no more visits in connection with this inspection.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The group at the summit of Oxen Craig - Craig Thomson is pictured th left"  Craig ascends Bennachie  times viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: kintore flats plans raise objections
story: Councillors will next week debate proposals for  new affordable flats in the heart of Kintore which have attracted a host of objections.Langstane Housing Association has tabled plans for four property blocks featuring  one-bed flats and six two-bed flats on vacant waste ground on Forest Road.But  objections have been raised on the grounds of insufficient parking and road safety, increased traffic and congestion on Forest Road and the scale of the development and the adverse impact on the amenity.In a report to Aberdeenshire Council’s Garioch Area Committee which meets on Tuesday, director of infrastructure services Stephen Archer says that “on balance” while the development may have an amenity impact on the neighbouring properties, it will fall within acceptable standards.He says: “The proposal for  affordable flats would make a positive contribution to affordable housing provision in Kintore.“It is accepted that any development on this site will alter the outlook from neighbouring dwellings, however, the use of the site for a flatted development is considered compatible with the infill nature of the site and settlement location.”Councillors will be told that the pre-application consultations and discussions during the determination of the application to reduce the potential impact on the neighbouring properties has resulted in the final layout and design.But in its objection, Kintore Community Council slams the proposal, particularly in terms of inadequate parking spaces.Chair Fiona Cooper states: “The proposed parking for the development of  spaces for  residents is insufficient and would result in overspill parking on the oppositie side of the road which would obviously have a major affect on existing residents.”In terms of the scale of the development, the community council recommends a maximum of two-storeys, with Mrs Cooper adding: “The proposed development by reason of size is out of character and would have an unacceptably adverse impact on the amenities of the properties immediately opposite the site and the surrounding area by reason of overlooking and having a visually overbearing impact.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk title: nominations wanted for community council
story: Nominations are being sought to fill  vacancies on Bennachie Community Council.Ideally the Community Council is looking for representation from the settlements of Chapel of Garioch, Culsalmond, Insch, Oyne, Premnay and Rayne.Completed forms must be ed by  pm on Monday, March .An election will only take place on Tuesday, March from . pm and . pm at Insch Institute,nominees exceed the vacancies.The community council’s meeting following the election is due to take place on Monday  March  in the Insch Institute.Nomination forms are now available to collect from the Garioch Area Office in Gordon House on Blackhall Road, Inverurie or email garioch@aberdeenshire.gov.uk.Forms are also available from the Community Council by emailing bennachiecc@outlook.Forms can also be found locally in N S Wilson, Chemist, Insch.For further information about the vacancies please email Alison Cumming Alison.cumming@aberdeenshire.gov.uk or call  .Further information on community councils can be found online here or visit wwwmunitycouncils.scot.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Last years top price animal, a champion heer, sold for #,"  Strong entry of calves for Spring Show viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: playgroup donates nativity cash to charity
story: A north east charity has received a welcome cash boost from an Inverurie playgroup.St Andrew’s Church Playgroup held a Nativity show just before Christmas and the event raised more than £.Through kind donations from parents, grandparents and other family members, as well as cash from raffle sales and refreshments, a total of £, was raised.The playgroup decided to donate the money to Spikin Autism and More , a parent peer support group for families or carers that have children with autism or other disabilities.The group provides a welcoming, relaxed environment for parents to not only share experiences, resources and information to help their children, but also to reduce their own feelings of ‘being alone’ and to provide one another with some much needed supportRepresentatives from the charity visited the playgroup on Friday, January  to accept the donation.Speaking to the Herald, Lisa Moir of SAAM said: “The money will go towards organising training sessions that will provide help on topics including dyslexia, speech and language.“We previously receviedfunding from the Garioch Partnership so we will add this money to that.“We want to help give more people the opportunity to have access to help with childcare issues.“The training sessions are open to everyone and we hope to have day and evening workshops.”Spikin Autism and More is based in Alford but started Peer Support Sessions at Homestart Garioch just over a year ago.Lisa created the group following the death of her husband.She added: “After he died I found it quite isolating finding support to raise our son who was three at the time and diagnosed with autism.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: to move or not to move that is the brexit question
story: Should people hold off putting those for sale signs up until the summer To move or not to move A study by the HomeOwners Alliance found that just  per centof people said their decision to stay where they are was based on concerns over Brexit, with more popular answers relating to lack of suitable homes and property prices.Russell Quirk, founded and CEO of hybrid estate agent Emoov said:ldquoThis research shows that Brexit isnrsquot the driving factor behind many UK home sellers looking to move or stay put and while we have seen the market slow due to the uncertain future of our partnership with the EU, the market is showing positive signs of recovery across the board.ldquoWhile this may strengthen once a Brexit deal is finalised there is no guarantee as to the outcome, and so those looking to sell should rest assured that now is as good a time as any to sell their home and later might not necessarily be better.Property commentator and buying agent Henry Pryor told the HomeOwners Alliance that he didnrsquot think that Brexit would have an impact straight away.ldquoJust like New Years Eve  when people wonderedplanes would fall out of the sky ortheir microwave would stop working because of the Millennium Bug I expect that March  will have a similar effect.ldquoWho seriously lsquoknowsrsquo what the impact of our actual orce from Europe will be ldquoThe three Drsquos will continue to provide a supply of sellers over the next year ndash death, debt and orce wonrsquot wait for Mrs May and Co to sort this out but there will be far fewer buyers who lsquomustrsquo purchase.ldquoAs a professional buyer, I am expecting to be especially busy as the more squeamish buyers ask for help making what in more normal times might be considered insulting offers. Brexiteers may claim that like other lsquoProject Fearrsquo predictions the anticipated damage to house prices has not been felt but I suspect they will be a bit more muted in a years time.If the Government negotiates a deal with the EU before March nothing will change until December , .The overriding answer seems to be that there is too much uncertainty at the moment soyou feel it is the right time to move, do it.Read more: Should I renew my EHIC card or will Brexit make it invalid data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.cumbernauld-news webimage ..! title: strong entry of calves for spring show
story: Some of the best commercial calves in the country will be forward at the Royal Northern Spring Show, held in conjunction with Aberdeen and Northern Marts.The annual event, which will be held at the Thainstone Centre on Wednesday, February , has attracted a strong entry of  calves from noted breeders.John and Craig Robertson from Newton of Logierait, Pitlochry, regularly dominate the show and sale, having scooped the supreme championship six times since . Last year, they sold the top price animal at £, for their champion heer and sold three others for £,, £, and £,.This year, the Robertsons have  calves entered including a full sister to last year’s top price heer.Huntly and Insch duo, Blair Duffton and Rebecca Stuart, will alsoto this year’s event with five calves, as will Ian Miller of Miller Farms, North Lurg, Midmar, who has four calves entered.Judging the commercial cattle entries, which will occur following the show and sales of bulls, will be well-known pedigree and commercial producer, Melanie Alford.John Angus, head of livestock at Thainstone, said: “The livestock sale element of the Royal Northern Spring Show is a fast-growing part of the event and we are delighted to be working once again with the Royal Northern Agricultural Society. The Spring Show is now recognised as the number one place for buyers from near and far to come and source quality calves with further showing potential.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"DIGG Councillor Martin Ford"  Councillors keen to prevent cuts viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Saturday  Feb  : PM

title: airports chairwoman is appointed
story: IT HAS been announced by Cabinet Secretary for Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity, Michael Matheson MSP, that Lorna Jack had been appointed as chairwoman of the Board of Highlands and Islands Airports Limited , operators of several airports, including Kirkwall Airport.Ms Jack is a chartered accountant and a graduate of Aberdeen University. She joined the Board of Highlands and Islands Airports Limited as a non-executive director in March  and chaired its Audit Committee for over three years, until she was invited to take on the interim chair role in October .Ms Jack remains the chief executive of the Law Society of Scotland and is an independent member of the Court of University of Aberdeen and a member of its Governance and Nominations Committee. She is also a trustee and treasurer of the McConnell International Foundation.The appointment is regulated by the Commissioner for Ethical Standards in Public Le in Scotland.• Highlands and Islands Airports Limitedis a public body wholly owned by Scottish Ministers. title: bus feedback events to return
story: Following the success of the event held in February , Bus Users Scotland willto Orkney this month to run another “Your Bus Matters” event to hear feedback on the bus services on the island. The events are open to everyone and will be held in Kirkwall and Stromness.The events give everyone the opportunity to provide feedback on what is working and what doesn’t about the local bus service. Representatives from Stagecoach will also be present to hear feedback on the services provided on the island.Greig Mackay, deputy director for Bus Users Scotland said: “We are looking forward to ing to Orkney to hear the views of the bus passengers. We were really pleased with the engagement at our event last year and look forward to hearing from more of the locals on the bus services on the island.”The two meetings will take place, later this month. title: power cable fault results in rackwick work
story: A faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, has resulted in work being carried out at Rackwick Bay in Hoy.A Scottish and Southern Energy Networks spokesman said: “SSEN can confirm there is a network fault affecting one of the two electricity distribution cables that connect Orkney to the Scottish mainland. Following a fault investigation process, damage has been located to a section of the Pentland Firth East cable near the shore at Rackwick Bay, Hoy.“There is no impact to customer supplies on Orkney as a result of the fault and contingency measures are in place, including the potential operation of the backup power station at Kirkwall, supported by mobile generation sets, to ensure a safe and secure supply of electricity for customers.“SSEN is committed to ing the network to normal operation as soon as possible and has instigated a repair plan. Following the receipt of the necessary permissions from statutory authorities late last week, work to undertake a sectional cable replacement is now under way.#The statement added: #It is expected this work, which will be contingent on tidal flows and weather conditions, will be complete early next week, with the line re-energised shortly after.“As part of SSEN’s subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is already at an advanced stage of development, with cable installation and commissioning currently due to take place in autumn next year.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: views sought on cursiter quarry expansion plans
story: Orkney Islands Council is providing a further opportunity for the public to view and comment on plans to expand Cursiter Quarry in Firth.The Council is due to submit a planning application for the long-term development of Cursiter Quarry in Firth this Spring.As part of a -phased expansion plan designed to secure additional reserves the quarry could increase in size over the next three decades expanding into neighbouring fields. The planning application also covers landscaping and future restoration of the site.The application process is being handled by consultants AECOM.The council-owned quarry currently supplies stone and aggregate materials for Council roads and building projects as well as the local construction industry.  It extracts Devonian Flagstone which is highly suited to a range of crushed aggregate products, in particular as roadstone and aggregates, used for producing asphalt for road construction and maintenance, with the quarry being the only active producer of asphalt in Orkney.The activity at the quarry generates an income for the Council which is reinvested to provide and protect some of the vital services we provide in Orkney.The current quarry area is heading towards the end of its use and an expansion would safeguard supply of materials. Current output ranges between , and , tonnes of rock per year andapproved, the ha expansion will release approximately  million tonnes of additional resources, sufficient for another  years of production.Full details are available on the Council website at http:www.orkney.gov.uk Council C long-term-development-of-cursiter-quarry-in-firth.htmPersons wishing to provide comments on the proposed development can do so by writing to AECOM at fraser.blackwood@aecom or by post to Fraser Blackwood, APEX ,  Haymarket Terrace, Edinburgh, EH HD by  February .OIC says that, at this stage, comments made to Aecom are for the purposes of assisting with the scheme design and EIA process and as such are not representations to the Planning Authority. title: Black Isle cafes Brexit talk ban raises cash for worthy cause
story: The tongue-in-cheek bid to banish the Brexit blues at Rosemarkie Beach Cafeacute over the festive season saw customers warned theyrsquod face a pound finethey so much as mentioned a word seldom out of the headlines lately.Philip Eley, the long-standing cafeacute manager, explained. ldquoItrsquos just grim. People are so depressed. Folk come to the beach to get away from all those headlines about what the idiots in Westminster are up to, but it only takes one person to mention the B-word to ruin everyone rsquos bacon roll.Customers warmed to the idea and willingly dropped contributions in the bucket during visits to the Black Isle beauty spot.Mr Eleyrsquos partner, Verity Walker, made good on a promise to donate takings from the offbeat bucket collection to the Maggiersquos Highlands cancer care centre at Raigmore Hospital. It was gratefully accepted by fundraising manager David Walker, who is no relation. Ms Walker said: ldquoWe finally got the donations bucket and collecting can to the Maggiersquos Centre at Raigmore ndash they were quite heavy as we kept them on the counter a bit longer and you just kept on giving!ldquoMaggiersquos has helped a number of cafeacute customers and staff. They exist to support those who are affected by cancer, but that includes the families of those diagnosed. If you have never been in, please go and visit, itrsquos a lovely calm space amid the hustle and bustle of Raigmore.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Black Isle festival issues tongue in cheek invite to ex Oasis star
story: The announcement last week that Noel Gallagher and his High Flying Birds will take to the stage in Inverness on June  was greeted with delight by fans of the multimillion-selling star who shot to fame as the creative force behind Oasis.Less thrilled about the timing of the Bught Park gig, organised by Live in the City and boasting support from Razorlight and Neon Waltz, were the organisers of the Black Isle-based Woodzstock, scheduled to take place on the same date in an outdoor adventure park near Tore, just a few miles from Gallaghers headline-grabbing gig.Woodzstock organisers Charlotte and Dave Elliott admit they were rocked ndash and not in a good way ndash when they learned of the clash. Within hours they rallied with a defiant show must go on plan ndash to invite Gallagher to perform at their intimate venue ahead of his own show in the Highland capital.Charlotte said: "Were excited that big names like Noel Gallaghers High Flying Birds are coming to the Highlands andwe werent holding our festival on the same day we would have loved to see them play. We didnt want to miss him so were inviting Noel to come along and play a few tunes at Woodzstock before his gig in Inverness."She added: "We know it a long shot! Were asking the public to help us by posting online sharing the hashtag #GetNoeltoWoodz"Now entering its third year, Woodzstock has grown year on year with more bands, festival-goers and local businesses, including food producers, artists and performers, sound engineers and local charities, benefiting.Charlotte said: "This year promises to the best Woodzstock yet, we have some fantastic bands already booked, amazing locally sourced food and drink and activities running for the kids. An appearance from Noel would be amazing. We hope our invitation reaches him and he knows our stage will be ready for him".No one from Live in the City was available for comment on the fixture clash. Mr Gallagher could not be reached for comment.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Easter Ross gymnastics club storms to national success
story: GOLDEN girls from a flourishing Easter Ross gymnastics club thrilled judges to take a top title only six months after starting a new discipline.Fyrish Gymnastics Clubrsquos success at the  Scottish National TeamGym Championships held at Meadowmill Sports Centre in Tranent last weekend.came after the Alness-based Scottish Gymnastics club of the year made the eight-hour round trip to compete against well-established TeamGym clubs Irvine Bay, Forth Valley, Midlothian and Saltire.The discipline is credited with keeping gymnasts involved in the sport longer. The open level  team stole the show with their floor routine which clinched gold ndash and the Scottish national title, only six months after starting the discipline.Fyrish TeamGym head coach, Heidi Bavnhoslashj, said: ldquoItrsquos quite amazing, we were all crying! We started in August and now wersquove won! One of the judges came over to compliment us on our floor routine so I thought we might get a bronze ndash but never did I think we could win!ldquoThese girls, their parents and the club have provided the best support. We started off with eight gymnasts interested [in TeamGym] now we are up to . Itrsquos going to keep more gymnasts involved in the sport longer as the club have really embraced it.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Easter Ross Post Offices affected by shops move
story: SHOP closures in two Easter Ross towns could leave the Post Office seeking new premises from which to operate.The changes affect Invergordon and Tain.A Post Office spokesperson said: ldquoWe are aware that our partner CJ Lang who runs Invergordon Post Office, has given us notice and the store will be closing later this year.ldquoThe branch was run independently and while we always work hard to maintain Post Office services, from time to time, branches do temporarily close. When this happens, we always look to restore services as quickly as possible, as we know how important Post Offices are to communities.ldquoWe would like to reassure customers that we are committed to maintaining vital Post Office services for the local community.The spokesman also confirmed that in Tain its partner McCollrsquos Retail Group, which runs the Post Office, has also given notice ldquoand the store will be closing in the spring.He said that branch is also run independently and efforts will be made to restore services as quickly as possible.He said: ldquoWe have had interest from some local retailers who are interested in running this branch but it is very early stages so we are unable to comment further at the moment. ldquoWe would like to reassure customers that we are committed to maintaining vital Post Office services for the local community ndash including banking services like cash withdrawals from high street bank account, bill payments, and of course a wide range of postal services.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland air traffic controllers to be balloted on strike action
story: A BALLOT that could lead to strike action resulting in disruption to flights across the Highlands is due to open next week.The Prospect union confirmed it is going ahead with the ballot of air traffic control members at Highlands and islands airports in a dispute over pay with their employers, Highlands and Islands Airports Ltd .The ballot will run from February  to March  andmembers back industrial action, a series of one-day strikes could start on April  and run throughout the summer.As well as affecting Inverness Airport operations could also be disruptedat Benbecula, Dundee, Kirkwall, Stornoway, Sumburgh and Wick John OGroats.Members are also being askedthey wish to take action short of an all-out strike that could include working to rosters an overtime ban and refusing extensions to airport opening hours for non-medical flights.David Avery, Prospect negotiations officer, said: ldquoMembers do not wish to take this action but have been forced into this position by the refusal of ministers to engage with the issue of air traffic controllersrsquo pay.Hial is owned by the Scottish Government which last week said all staff had been given a pay rise which was a ldquosignicant improvement on previous years.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: New homes planned for Dingwall
story: DINGWALL moved a step closer to getting  new homes after the Ross and Cromarty area committee agreed an infrastructure investment ldquounlocking the possibility of the development.But councillors were at odds over the plans with some considering them a sop in lieu of the  homes earmarked for the town since  while others said it was a ldquopositive move in a high pressure area for housing demand.The original plan was based on the delivery of the Kinnairdie Link Roadproject ndash expected to unleash millions in inward investment. It was due to start its final phase of construction this year but it was axed from the councilrsquos capital programme in last yearrsquos budget.Then in March, funding for transport improvements in Dingwall was found to enable some housing development to take place prior to the commencement of the KLR.A transport study and modelling work considered the impact of ious levels of development in the town and improvements will include work at the Bridgend Avenue Junction and Docharty Road Junction as well as traffic signal works at Mart Road Junction. Proposals for walking and cycling improvements and traffic management measures will also be brought forward to enhance active travel facilities in the town.Dingwall and Seaforth councillor Graham Mackenzie said: ldquoIt would be tempting to see it as a good news story for Dingwall. That is not the case. Had we been given what we were promised in an earlier iteration of the capital plan we could be releasing up to  houses for development instead of around ."Instead the KLR was taken out of the capital plan even though the first phase of the project had already started. If Dingwall is to grow and provide the range of housing which is required, the KLR must be moved up the list of priorities. This project needs to be reinstated.Fellow ward councillor Angela Maclean insisted the deal was good news. She said: ldquoWe as councillors have a leadership role and it is up to us to be helping our communities to move forward and this report has examples of when officers have looked for solutions to get round some of the fact that we donrsquot have all the money we would like."Whether it is through the infrastructure road plans or capital fund we are going to try and move forward with these houses in Dingwall, because Dingwall is a pressurised area ndash this is a positive move because we donrsquot have enough houses in Dingwall.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Old office goes back on market in Dingwall
story: The former assessorrsquos office in Ferry Road, which adjoins the old Sherf Court, dates back to .A category B listed commercial property it was on the market a year ago and it was thought a buyer had been found. But the sale fell through and the property is again up for sale with offers over pound, invited.Originally built as a police station, the property has a colourful history with its location next to the courthouse.The sherf court was closed by the Scottish Court Service in January  as part of a cost-cutting and restructuring scheme.The following year the property was sold and converted into a private dwelling. The former police station been used for many years by Highland Council as offices for the assessor.The assessor is responsible for assigning a value to properties for tax purposes.Because it was a commercial property it is not necessary to provide a survey of the building to potential buyers.It is in a mix of modern and traditional residential properties close to the town centre on Ferry Road.Of stone and slate construction it comprises three rooms on the ground floor and four rooms on the first floor.A council spokesman said the property requires extensive work, but it has its own entrance and parking to the front of the property.The closing date set for offers is March , .Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Parents blast council for not seeking cash to fix crumbling Dingwall school
story: SOME of the most vulnerable pupils in Ross-shire have been treated with "utter contempt" by the local authority which has misled parents and failed to seek "a single penny" of extra cash from the Scottish government.That was the damning indictment this week ahead of a crunch meeting on the future of St Clements in Dingwall before Highland Council sets its budget.Members of the parent-teacher council have already written to every single councillor urging them to take long-promised action to resolve severe problems with school building declared unfit for purpose by the governments childrens minister.The Scottish Government has confirmed the local authority has not sought funding for St. Clementrsquos from the the Scotland Schools for the Future programme.The next tranche of the pound billion announced last November will only be available from  leaving teachers and pupils enduring years more hardship in a building branded "Dickensian" by local MSP Kate Forbes.A Scottish government spokesman said: ldquoWe have been made aware that St. Clementrsquos is in poor condition, however it is the statutory responsibility of Highland Council to manage and maintain its school estate.ldquoThe Scottish government has provided signicant funding of over poundm in recent years towards five projects through its existing school building programme, Scotland Schools for the Future, all of which were Highland Councilrsquos priority projects for investment. Highland Council has not asked the Scottish Government for support in relation to St Clementrsquos.Christyna Ferguson, whose daughter suffering a series of complex health issues including autism attends the school, slammed the councilrsquos inaction "utter contempt for the already disadvantaged, vulnerable children".She said: "The Highland Council repeatedly told us that St.Clementrsquos appalling lack of facilities was due to a lack of Scottish government funding. Therefore it is misleading at best and shows not only non-compliance with their statuary obligations but utter contempt for the children."In the last year the Highland Council has taken no action to survey sites, secure funding or build a business plan despite assuring us they would."She insisted: ldquoHighland Council does have options in terms of funding solutions but they repeatedly refuse to engage in the process ndash again failing in their statutory obligations and causing unnecessary suffering and detriment to disabled children. It is incomprehensible to me that those with the power and the obligation in law can show such blatant disregard for disabled children."Dingwall-based MSP Kate Forbes said: "As the daughter of a former teacher at St Clementrsquos, I am in no doubt as to the poor condition of the buildings. It is remarkable the teachers are able to care for and teach the pupils in such a damp, cramped building.ldquoThere is a desperate need for a new building, delivered in consultation with parents and teachers. This is, of course, a matter for Highland Council who are statutorily responsible for school buildings but I think everybody wants to see a solution."I am more than happy to work with anybody and everybody to find a solution and would sincerely hope that wersquore not still talking about school buildings in another  years."Childrenrsquos minister Maree Todd, also a Ross-shire-based SNP MSP, said: "The school has not previously been prioritised by Highland Council in their capital spending plans despite being in a poor condition."Itrsquos nearly a year since I first raised concerns with the council so I look forward to meeting with councillors and officers at the end of this month to hear an update on progress. All children, especially those who are disadvantaged and vulnerable, deserve our help to enable them to, not only fulfil, but to exceed their potential. That is why it is vital that we can find the right solution for the pupils, parents and the wider St Clementrsquos community.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: "At this point in time we are addressing our capital plan for next year and the process is still ongoing. The council has been in dialogue with Scottish Government and highlighted the  school locations, including St Clements, which were identied by the council in March  as priorities for bids to Scottish Government. We are not aware of any Scottish Government Funding prior to ."Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: People power sees safety measures considered for Tain junctions at last
story: HOPES are high that action will finally now be taken at two of the most dangerous road junctions in Easter Ross following a string of accidents and near-misses.Concerns about Tainrsquos two main junctions with the A prompted campaigners to claim a failure by roads chiefs to act would ldquoinevitably lead to someone being killed.Tain and Easter Ross councillor Derek Louden was joined by politicians from across the political spectrum in flagging up concerns, among them local MP Jamie Stone who said he had ldquopersonally witnessed more smashes than I care to remember and that ldquothere is something terribly wrong here.Campaigners had suggested a iety of possible measures, including reducing the speed limit, changing the road layout and even the installation of roundabouts ndash but their pleas fell on deaf ears.However, Transport Scotlandrsquos new area road safety manager, Richard Perry, has told Cllr Louden draft proposals have now been drawn up following an analysis of collisions at the north and south junctions by trunk road operator BEAR Scotland.Short-term measures could include enhanced signage, improved surfacing and better road markings.In the medium term, improvements to the bell mouth radius of the south junction will be considered.The possibility of reducing the speed limit on the bypass section to mph will also be investigated, but this would require statutory processes and consultation.Mr Perry said the construction of a roundabout could be considered, but would require agreement on funding.Cllr Louden told the Journal he was delighted to hear safety could finally be improved at the dangerous junctions.He welcomed the widening of the exits to allow lorries and buses to get onto the A without having to use the central reservation.And he title: Ross nurses lead the way
story: Chrissie Laneand Lucy Heycockentered the gruelling Strathpeffer -hour mountain bike challenge with the aim of encouraging some of their patients and colleagues to embrace new challenges and experiences.The annual event near Strathpeffer sees riders tackle freezing temperatures,  hours of darkness and mile upon mile of frozen forest tracks.The dynamic duo were delighted with a podium finish. Macmillan cancer consultant nurse Chrissie, from Culbokie, said: ldquoWe work every day with amazing people living with cancer and are trying to support them to be active outdoors which has huge proven benefits to their health and recovery.ldquoMaking small or big changes to the amount of moving your body does throughout the day have immense benefits for people living with cancer.Theyrsquore promoting everything from short walks and cycle rides to hillwalking.Chrissie added: ldquoThe reason why we took part in the event was to try to be role models for older woman to just give experiences a try. All it needs is a gritty frame of mind and a sense of humour and fun when situations are not so pleasant.Chrissie and advanced nurse colleague Lucy, from Muir of Ord, were delighted with a podium finish, coming in an extremely credible third in the competitionrsquos female pairs category.Both Chrissie and Lucy hope that their success shows that you can take up and enjoy exercise, even doing an event like the challenging Strathpuffer, at any age.Saturday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: first look at the jarls squad
story: Plenty of onlookers were already on the streets as the squad made its first procession of the day from Islesburgh Community Centre, past the galley shed on St Sunniva Street and on to the Toll Clock Shopping Centre.In the gloom, the ranks of the Jarl#s Squad looked the part wearing emerald green kirtles with dragon mots underneath simple brown leather breastplates embossed with the same mot. A animal skin cloak completes the look. the suit was very warm, a blessing on a day like today.If the breastplate is simple that is in contrast to the fierce-looking helmets which are designed to look like a dragon#s head, complete with #scales# hanging from the back of the helmets.Squad member Lynden Nicolson has spent hours working on the helmets and said he was thrilled with the way they had turned out. The axes are special too with the axe head crafted out of Damascus steel.Mr Nicolson was looking forward to the day ahead, saying: #It is brilliant to get here today and see everybody together. title: bringing shakespeare to a new generation
story: As well as staging the dark comedy a block of drama workshops are being put on to help the youngsters involved develop the skills needed to take part.The ethos behind the workshops is that they will show people that they need not be put off by Shakespeare and any notions that his work is #dficult, incomprehensible, archaic, intellectual#. In fact, his plays were written for the masses and the anniversary events will show participants how to get their tongue around some of the more unusual words and explain what they mean.This series of workshops are booked as a block and will allow participants to further develop their drama skills. They will culminate with a short sharing session for family and friends in the Mareel auditorium.Anyone aged between  and  can take part.The events are on Sundays th February and th March at the Garrison Theatre in Lerwick and on Sundays rd March and th March in Mareel. in Walls Community Garden. raquo..

title: halcro johnston welcomes comments from senior snp minister on ferry funding
story: Signs have emerged of a softening in the Scottish government#s approach to fair ferry funding, with one Tory MSP insisting a senior SNP colleague has given backing for a better deal on leline links.Isles councillors have been left frustrated by the Scottish government#s funding offer following its budget, not least because of a shortfall in ferry funding.Complaints have been made by island leaders that the funding settlement, agreed last year, does not meet the full costs of running the internal ferries in Orkney and in Shetland.In the Western Isles the costs are met by the Scottish government as part of Clyde and Hebridean ferry service contract.But Conservative MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston had highlighted a visit to Orkney by the SNP #s constitutional relations secretary, Mike Russell.Jamie Halcro JohnstonAccording to a news release dispatched on Thursday, Mr Russell told The Orcadian newspaper: “I can take that back, and I can say to my colleagues, look this is a big issue in Orkney, and obviously it needs a resolution”.Mr Halcro Johnston welcomed the cabinet secretary’s acknowledgement that a resolution was required and urged one to be brought forward.“I welcome news of Mike Russell’s comments on fair ferry funding, and I’m encouraged by the intervention of a senior SNP minister. As a representative for Argyll and Bute, Mr Russell clearly understands ferry issues rather better than some of his government colleagues.#It comes after the Scottish government agreed to alter its spending plans with support from the Scottish Greens.The Greens said the Scottish government had agreed to alter its spending plans in exchange for support in getting the budget through.SIC leader Steven Coutts told The Shetland Times on Thursday: #At the moment we#re still waiting to see the final full detail on the back of the deal that was done between the Green Party and the SNP. We need to see what the figures actually mean.#There#s still no commitment on full and fair ferry funding, and that#s something we#ll want to press the government and Green Party on.#..
